newsitem.title: ANGOLA: Kabila says security behind Zaire talks pullout.
newsitem.headline: Kabila says security behind Zaire talks pullout.

text.p: Zairean rebel leader Laurent Kabila said he abandoned plans to board a South African navy ship on Friday because of security concerns, but said he could still travel there on Saturday for peace talks.
"I am worried about security on the ship," Kabila told a Luanda news conference. "No one has told me about who is there or what their role is."
Kabila also said he was not happy that the composition of the negotiation group had been expanded without his knowledge.
"...And now I've learned that the president of Congo is on the boat. Now this is a surprise. Everyone knows he is a friend of Mobutu," the rebel leader said.

South African Deputy President Thabo Mbeki, who was meant to escort Kabila to the SAS Outeniqua navy ship for the first face- to-face talks with President Mobutu Sese Seko, was due to return to Luanda to brief Kabila about security measures on the ship, aides said.
Kabila, in reply to a question on how his decision not to attend the talks on Friday would be viewed by the international community, replied: "It is my security I am concerned about."
